headline: Apple Pie Filling
description: With this apple pie filling recipe, you can stock up on your favorite apple in season and make extra filling to freeze and enjoy all year long.

video.description: Whip up a batch when you have a lot of apples and store it in the freezer.
video.name: Apple Pie Filling

name: Apple Pie Filling

recipeInstructions.text: Place apples in a bowl. Toss apples with lemon juice in a large bowl and set aside.
Pour water into a Dutch oven over medium heat. Combine sugar, cornstarch, cinnamon, salt, and nutmeg in a bowl; add to water, stir well, and bring to a boil. Boil for 2 minutes, constantly stirring.
Add apples and return to a boil. Reduce heat, cover, and simmer until apples are tender, 6 to 8 minutes. Cool for 30 minutes.
Ladle into 5 freezer containers, leaving 1/2 inch of headspace. Cool at room temperature no longer than 1 1/2 hours.
Seal and freeze. Can be stored for up to 12 months.

review.reviewBody: I used 5 cups of water, as suggested by some. It was plenty. 10 cups would have been way too much. I hesitated at 1 cup corn starch, but it worked out well. Easy to do ( because I have an apple slicer lol). Looks delicious. Will use again.

I made this recipe several times and love it. However, I am very disappointed that All Recipes no longer offers the ability to automatically convert the size of servings. I want to pare the quantity down and find it tricky to work out the volume of water for a smaller portion and many reviewers seem to focus on too much liquid. I liked the older version of All Recipes better.
5 cups of water is plenty. I added a little more cinnamon and a pinch of cloves. I've made this recipe before and it always turns out great!
Super easy, I used 5 cups of water and it came out perfect.

This is a wonderful recipe, one I've used successfully for a couple of years. I found a bag of the filling in my freezer from 12 months ago that needed using. 
I had one pre-made pie crust on hand, so I lined a med. sized casserole dish with the crust, dumped in the thawed filling, folded and brushed butter on the exposed crust, and sprinkled it with a mixture of cinnamon and sugar. Voila, my own version of an apple galette! Yummy!
no way this needs 10 cups of water. I used 5 and it was still too much. I'd use 2 next time. I also cut the sugar in half.
Excellect way to preserve apples for winter apple pies
I loved it. it was easy to make and freeze and tastes awesome

Way, way too much liquid. I reduced this recipe for 2 pies, used 1/2 cider and 1/2 water with the cornstarch, sugar and spices. I used 8 cups of sliced apples. It looks like that I will have filling for one pie. I may try this again, reducing the liquid, and increasing the amount of apples. I used Golden Delicious apples, which is my "go to" apple for baking. I am planning on using the leftover liquid to make an apple crisp.
Makes a huge amount but it's delicious!

This is really good. I did add more cinnamon and since we don't care for traditional nutmeg I added some ginger. After reading other reviews about the liquid I did reduce it but used apple juice instead of water. Good frozen or canned.

This recipe was easy and turned out very well! Canning and freezing fruits and vegetables can be daunting for a beginner, which I am not. Just follow the recipe and go for it! I tweaked the spices a bit because my husband likes a very cinnamony taste in his apple pie. I also added a pinch of ground cloves. Thanks!

Loved the ease of making it. Mashed up some for fried pies with store bought dough and they turned out wonderful! Going to measure 3 cups and freeze for a pie and save the rest for pancake topping and more fried pies. I did scale the recipe down to use 9 cups of Granny Smith apples and cut apples into 2 inch chunks.
Easy as pie!!! This is my very first apple pie and I wanted to use a cooked filling. I was able to recruit my 10 year old daughter to help prepare and cook. This was delicious!
Great recipe and very easy. I agree with other reviews, however. It requires way too much liquid. This reduces the flavor of the spices. Next batch I'll reduce water and add more apples.

Om'goodness... This is amazing! I did modify the recipe a bit,(picked our own apples & used extra spices) but it's really good. It makes a lot.
Definitely recommend
I put a bit more cinnamon in it to make it a tablespoon. It is really delicious.
Awesome! Loved it!

I had some apples in the freezer and did not want them to go to waste thought what can I make looked up this amazing apple pie filling recipe it was very easy, for the amount of apples that I had I just halved the recipe., it worked great !!

I made this recipe on a scaled-down version and I found that it took longer to soften the apples then what it called for 6 to 8 minutes it took more like 20 minutes but it smells really good can hardly wait to make my first pie
It’s a winner in my house. I too cut water by half and increased apples a touch. Hubby is loving the year round pies, turnovers, pancakes. Good flavor and apple texture. This is a keeper.
Easy

This was amazing, I definitely recommend to any one who is preparing for thanksgiving. I will use this for the rest of my life! I also learned that if you forget into add sugar it tastes HORRIBLE. So before u store it in the fridge give it a taste test.

Made this as vanilla ice cream topping and scaled recipe to 3 servings. Served with Carmel sauce as well. Served my family of 4 without any leftover. I did dice the apples to make it easier to serve on the ice cream. Will definitely make again.
Yum!!! I had to scale down the recipe to accompany only four cups of chopped apples but golly it was tasty!
added ground cloves and vanilla
less sugar

Great starting place. I used 3c sugar, 1 1/2 c brown sugar, 1T cinnamon, 1tsp nutmeg, 1 tsp cloves. Way too much “sauce.” Next time I’ll do half the amount of wAter, 1/2 the called-for sugars, and half the called-for corn starch.

So I wanted an apple pie filling with some ooey gooey goodness and this delivered exactly that. I changed the number of servings from 40 to 10, I just wanted enough for one pie to try out the recipe. At 10 servings it says 4 and a half cups of apples, I used 5 because I like more apple pieces. It also called for 2 and a half cups of water and I used half of that. Everything else I followed. Made the filling, let it sit and cool a bit while I made my crust, and then cooked the pie like I normally would. I didn't see anyone else using the filling right away so I wanted to try it and let you know how it went...in case anyone else wondered if it would work out without freezing it ??
Made this as stated in recipe and would not change a thing. SO convenient! Did freeze in foil pie plates as reviewers suggested. Totally delicious, husband wouldn't leave it alone.
Delicious. I loved this filling.
Absolutely Delicious!!! Made pies, ice cream topping and just plain eating it with a spoon ;)

Terrific for apple picking season; I always end up with WAY more apples than I can eat right away.

Just as others suggested, I cut the amount of of water & cornstarch by a third. I also added 1/4 cup butter and 1 tsp more cinnamon.
Followed other people's suggestions about using less water, more apples and less cornstarch. Very good filling.
Tastes great, i should have used more apples, we sliced them into 8ths, with a wedge/corer cutter , but we can add fresh apples as i make the pies, Yes we will make this one again.
I halved the recipe. The original is a whole lot of apple pie makings and we won't eat that much in a year. Half was just perfect.
added more cinnamon
I have made this for 2 years. So good and so easy! Taste like my moms pie from years ago!
I used brown sugar ( slightly reduced the sugar amount)....tasted wonderfully carmelly!!
This came out a huge hit with my kids!! Made 2 pies and still have filling left over!! I did add 1/2 a cup of brown sugar also just because of our taste but it was perfect!

Just made this with my backyard apple tree, pink ladys. I had approximately 16 cups of sliced apples. I also after reading many of the reviews, cut back the water to 5 cups. I did 1/2 brown sugar and 1/2 granulated sugar. Cut back the corn starch to a heaping 1/2 cup. The rest I followed the recipe except I added a few shakes of vanilla powder. Oh I did increase the cinnamon to a heaping 3 tsp. Yummy!
This was excellent! I halved the recipe and filled some puff pastry. I will make it again and make the full recipe and freeze it. Thanks for a great recipe.
Made delicious pies, for deep dish I used two quarts pie filling. Made wonderful Christmas gifts with attaching some fabric on top along with my homemade jelly in decorative baskets.
definitely will make again. apples did not get mushy. husband loved apple pies all year
I will definitely make this again! I really like it. The only change I made was to decrease the water per the advice of some of the reviewers.
Turned out really good. I did make some adjustments mainly due to what I had on hand and my personal taste. Less water, more apples and more spices. Sooooooo easy. Thank you
I really loved this recipe! I did use a lot less water for just a half batch and it turned out perfect! I was curious though as to whether I could sub in other fruits.
It was delicious. I will probably make it again but I will add more cinnamon.
So simple, and so delicious. Thank you for this recipe!

Nice and thick. I did 8 cups of Granny Smith apples and did just under 1/2 cup corn flower, I used allspice and 1/2 teaspoon of cinnamon because I didn't have enough cinnamon. 8 cups of apples is about right for one pie. I also used 2 cups of white sugar and just mixed all ingredients in which worked fine. You can’t really stuff this recipe up to be honest and you can easily make additions to suit your preferences.

This recipe is good for giving a great method for freezing filling but the quantities didn't work for me (as other reviewers have mentioned). After some trial and error, I found what works for us. 
For 2 pies I used 3 # Granny Smith apples, 2 tsp. lemon juice, 2 1/2 cups water, 1 cup sugar, 1/4 corn starch, 1 tsp. cinnamon, 1/4 tsp. salt, 1/4 tsp. ginger, 1/8 tsp. nutmeg.

Question...
Any thoughts on preparing this in a Crock-Pot?
Thanks :)
I will never buy canned filling again
This is a great recipe, hope it freezes and unfreezes well. Taste delish

I made this recipe as written. I did indeed have an excessive amount of liquid. That being said I was able to remove some via a colander and big bowl. Reserving the liquid for later I was able to make pies. The time saved alone in making pies gets me to give four stars the fifth came from the taste. I took the remaining liquid and reduced it until it was nice and thick. I added about four tablespoons of butter and made a nice apple pie caramel sauce. Made the Apple pie ala mode I had even better! Orchard apples are definitely juicier than store bought apples. So if you don’t have the time or patience to make a nice sauce then reduce cooking water to at least eight cups. Adjust corn starch to suit thickness of your sauce. Over all it’s a recipe I will use again and again.

I made a pie from it and used a butter pie crust recipe. It was delicious. I read the reviews and it seemed a general consensus to cut down the amount of water used. I took the advice and ended up using 6 cups of water and a little more cinnamon than called for. It was delicious. I would probably divide the recipe into 3 containers instead of 5. I like deep dish apple pie. Thanks for sharing the recipe. I'd share a picture, but it's pretty much gone.

As others suggested, I added some nutmeg and cloves and used half white and half brown sugar. I also reduced the water to 4 cups since I was using fresh picked apples. I think I could have reduced it even more. The final product tastes delicious - so much better than filling from a can! I can’t wait to bake a pie!
Question: How many apples and which kind?

Very good! I will be adding this one to my book. The only changes I made was 1/2 the water and 1/2 brown sugar and 1/2 white sugar. I made 1 pie and put the rest in bags for my seal machine and froze for latter on. Thanks
Way to much liquid, but the taste was amazing. I canned the finished product to save for the winter months. Can't wait to make a Thanksgiving pie with the contents!
Cut the recipie in half worked well added a little more spice taste great held together great after coolong
Good apple pie filling. And I love the idea of bulk preparation for freezing and later quick use. First dish I made with this was a Apple Streusel that the whole family enjoyed.
Pretty good!
Question? Is it 1 cup of cornstarch cause that seems like a lot. just wondering?:)
Great little filling. Nice and thick! Had to throw out some of the juice, just not enough apple lol made a double batch.
This is easy to adapt to however many apples you have, and it is excellent. Just Apple pie filling!
The absolute BEST pie crust I have made!!! Thank you :))))
Perfection! A little more cinnamon and nutmeg cause I like them, but turned out perfectly.
I made this with no changes other than I didn't make that large amt. it is so good. will be using this again.

I actually cut back on the servings I made with this as I wanted a homemade apple pie filling that made less. I used it in a 2 ingredient recipe which was very easy to make. I thought it had a little too much cinnamon but my husband loved it. Ate most of what I made in 2 days and raved about how good it was. So glad you can scale down recipes on this site if you need to. Thanks for the recipe.
I just made this and I couldn 't be more pleased. It's easy, excellent taste and aroma. It is definitely a recipe I will use many more times.
Far too much water for 18 cups of apples...next time i will use only 5 cups...also I added more sugar and more seasoning
Makes great apple sauce too.

perfect! makes a lot so I had to can most of it. cooked the apples a lot longer that 8 min. I like them soft not crunchy. excellent recipe for apple pie, friend apple pies, or just eat right out of the bowl while hot! puts friend apples to shame!
Went to make a "half batch" with some apple orchard Haralson apples. Turned out delicious!

Used Granny Smith apples and made the recipe exactly as described. Just had 1/2 cup of the apples after they cooled and they are wonderful! Looking forward to making my caramel apple pies (dot with chopped soft Werther's caramels before top crust) for the Holidays without all of the fuss and mess. ;o)
Great recipe! The only changes I made were to add a half tsp cinnamon and a pinch more nutmeg. I also cut the recipe in 3, as I only had 6 cups of apples.
I added more cinnamon and it is amazing. Not sure what I will add to the crust when I bake it but it is yummy right out of the pan!

Update: I made some Jack-o-Lantern Apple Hand Pies. First, reduce the recipe to 8 servings. Only use 1/2 cup of water. Cut the apples in small pieces. Follow the rest of the directions. Make your own pie crust or use store bought pie crust. I made 12 hand pies using a 3 inch biscuit cutter. Add about 2 - 3 tsp. of filling in the middle. Add a stem use water to wet dough to add stem. Use a small sharp paring knife to cut a pumpkin face on the top of one of the circles. Use your finger to wet the rim of the bottom circle. Add top and seal. Crimp edges with a fork. Brush the hand pie with an egg wash. Sprinkle orange sprinkles on top. Spray a foil lined pan with cooking spray. Bake for 14 min at 375 degrees or until done. To freeze pie filling: This was an excellent recipe. I did follow the suggestions of other people who reviewed this recipe. I used 1/2 of the water, increased the cinnamon and added nutmeg. The pie filling came out perfect. It was the first time freezing any type of fruit filling. Next Fall, I will get a bushel of apples and make some pie filling to have for the whole year.
Very tasty! I followed the recipe except to halve the amount of water and cornstarch used like others suggested. This gave it a very nice apple to sauce ratio.
Excellent recipe!
Very delicious over vanilla ice cream!
reduced water to 6 cups and it was great.I had enough filling to freeze for 6 pies which i will use for hunting camp in november. thank you.
I really like this recipe and so does everyone in the family. But I agree with some of the other comments about cutting back on the amount of water probably by about a 1/3.

Other reviewers suggested reducing the water by half, which I did and I have a nice thick tasty filling. May use a little less sugar next time as I like it a little tart.
I used Granny Smith apples from the grocery.
Perfect. Made as written, and loved it. Now my go to filling recipe. Now....if you could just peel,core and trim my apples, I'd be even happier!
Great taste and easy to put together.
I scaled the recipe down, but made it as directed. It's good, and so easy. I might try a bigger batch next time to save for later.

I adjusted the recipe to 10 servings and used honey instead of sugar. Loved it! ? 10 servings will produce between 2-3 pies, depending on how much you fill them. I suggest doubling the cinnamon, or else the flavor will not be noticeable. Also, add an extra bit of cornstarch for a less runny filling.
Besides being a really large amount, this recipe is delicious! I've made it with the recipe measurements and also by cutting it in half. This is definitely my favorite apple pie recipe.

Made 5 of these pies (one recipe) for my church's big fund-raiser. I did the 2 c brown sugar 2 c white w/ 1 c cornstarch, 2 tsp cinnamon and 1 tsp allspice. I used 6 c water, and then gradually added more at times when it looked too thick, or was heating up too fast (all those apples to peel!). 

Also, I originally only made four pies (7 large granny smith apples, 2 medium gala apples and 9 small 'premium' apples). It was enough to fill four 9" foil-lined pie plates albeit to a low enough level that I worried they would end up sunken when baked (they didn't, they were flat but fine). 

However, I had so much left-over 'syrup' that I decided to make a fifth pie for us. 8-9 smallish granny smith apples filled up a 10' deep dish glass pie plate. All I had to do was add some water and re-heat the 'syrup', then make it the same as before.

Also: I used the Make Ahead Pie Crust by SUPERMOMOF4 for these pies and it worked well--see my review of it.

My only issues with this filling is two: one, it takes MUCH LONGER to bake frozen filling. I tried the 15 min @ 450, 35 min @ 350 time and NOPE--the filling would be barely lukewarm. I always ended up sticking it back in for another half hour. Upping the time at 450 resulted in an overly-browned crust, so by the time I was baking the last pies I went with 15 min @ 450, 50 min @ 350. 

Issue two: this filling simply doesn't compare in taste to Grandma Ople's (also on allrecipes). It's good, but a little bland; it doesn't explo

I have made two pies from this recipe (with two to go)! Delicious. I did reduce the sugar per some of the other reviews and it was just great. I might up the cinnamon next time I make this. The consistency was perfect and did not leak all over the pie plate. A homemade pie crust (using a little vodka) made it the perfect pie that sat beautifully on the dessert plate. I got the crust recipe from a well known instructional cook book. This is my new go-to recipe when I have lots of apples!
This recipe is amazing. I will use this for all my apple pies! Thank you so much!!!

I made mine with just 8 cups water and it was still too much,....! Cut water back by 2-3 cups and subtract 1-2 cups sugar as well! Make a slurry of the corn starch with COLD water, than add in a drizzle, whisking constantly,.....adding the apples last.
This pie filling makes the best pies. My family loves it! I also love how easy it is to make up 5 pie fillings at once and then freeze them for later.
I love this recipe. Make it all the time. I use apple juice insted of water. Corn starch to thicken as needed.

Excellent recipe. Made twice, first as directed, second time, I tweaked from my knowledge and experience of baking. Two things:

If using Granny Smith apples, keep the sugar. Any other, i.e. Golden Delicious, Honeycrisp, etc., consider reducing sugar by at least a quarter. I reduced by half when using Honeycrisps.

Perfect 'easy' recipe as-is for topping pancakes, french toast, waffles, ice cream, etc. REDUCE WATER by at least a third (I went half, had extra juicy apples) if using as a pie filling. Soppy, soggy mess otherwise.Terrific freezer recipe, especially for use as a topper. Thus, 5 stars for versatility and ease, 4 for flavor and consistency. I have put away 12 pints of this recipe for use at brunches, breakfast and desserts. Thank you for a great recipe.

I did enjoy this recipe, however, I followed Vicky Gunkel's advice (most positive review) and cut back on the water and cornstarch and added more apples. Loved the filling and it was a great way to make use of our abundant crop of apples this year! Yum!

I made 1/2 batch last year and canned it. It made great pie. I used Mutsu apples which are huge (each apple makes 2 cups). This year I made a full recipe and canned it. Because I canned it, hot water bath for 20 minutes, I didn't cook it for more than a minute or two after adding the apples. I got 6 quarts, plus a pint and a half of extra syrup which will be great over pancakes or waffles.
